articles.headline: A Supreme Court in Disarray After an Extraordinary Breach
articles.snippet: The leak of a draft majority opinion overruling Roe v. Wade raises questions about motives, methods and whether defections are still possible.
articles.abstract: The leak of a draft majority opinion overruling Roe v. Wade raises questions about motives, methods and whether defections are still possible.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sources have motives, and the leaked draft opinion overturning Roe v. Wade raises a question as old as the Roman Empire. Cui bono? Who benefits?

articles.headline: Europe Is About to Ban Russian Oil: What’s Next?
articles.snippet: Policymakers want to stop financial support to a war machine. Replacing that energy supply is going to be difficult and expensive for consumers.
articles.abstract: Policymakers want to stop financial support to a war machine. Replacing that energy supply is going to be difficult and expensive for consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia’s decades-long dominance of Europe’s energy market is crumbling, and the biggest blow is expected this week as the European Union moves toward a ban on Russian oil.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed, Melissa Eddy and Benjamin Novak

articles.headline: Leaked Threat to Roe v. Wade Stuns, Then Energizes Americans
articles.snippet: Supporters and opponents of abortion rights were anticipating a Supreme Court decision this summer, but the sudden release of a draft opinion set off a wave of impromptu protests.
articles.abstract: Supporters and opponents of abortion rights were anticipating a Supreme Court decision this summer, but the sudden release of a draft opinion set off a wave of impromptu protests.
articles.lead_paragraph: Opponents and supporters of abortion rights had expected for months that the Supreme Court would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade, but the leaked draft opinion late Monday came as if out of the blue, setting off shock, outrage and jubilation on both sides of the nation’s deeply polarized abortion debate.
articles.byline: By Kate Zernike, Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham

articles.headline: Vance Wins Republican Senate Primary in Ohio After Nod From Trump
articles.snippet: J.D. Vance, the author of “Hillbilly Elegy,” won a G.O.P. race that saw nearly $80 million in television advertising.
articles.abstract: J.D. Vance, the author of “Hillbilly Elegy,” won a G.O.P. race that saw nearly $80 million in television advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — J.D. Vance, the best-selling author whose “Hillbilly Elegy” about life in Appalachia illuminated a slice of the country that felt left behind, decisively won the Ohio Senate primary on Tuesday after a late endorsement by Donald J. Trump helped him surge past his rivals in a crowded field.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Jazmine Ulloa

articles.headline: The Fed Is Set to Pull Back Economic Help Rapidly. Is It Too Late?
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials took a while to recognize that inflation was lasting. The question is whether they can tame it gently now.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials took a while to recognize that inflation was lasting. The question is whether they can tame it gently now.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is poised to set out a path to rapidly withdraw support from the economy at its meeting on Wednesday — and while it hopes it can contain inflation without causing a recession, that is far from guaranteed.

articles.headline: American Importers Accuse Shipping Giants of Profiteering
articles.snippet: Carriers are exploiting the supply chain chaos to breach contracts and jack up rates, importers say in asking for federal intervention.
articles.abstract: Carriers are exploiting the supply chain chaos to breach contracts and jack up rates, importers say in asking for federal intervention.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Reich assumed that a contract was a contract.

articles.headline: Leak Heightens the Perception of a Politicized Supreme Court
articles.snippet: Even some harsh critics of Roe v. Wade see a court that reflects and amplifies the nation’s political divides.
articles.abstract: Even some harsh critics of Roe v. Wade see a court that reflects and amplifies the nation’s political divides.
articles.lead_paragraph: The revelation of a Supreme Court draft opinion that would overrule Roe v. Wade has caused many Americans to express doubts about whether the justices are guided by the law rather than by their political beliefs.
articles.byline: By Shawn Hubler and Michael Wines
